tossups.question: Abadan and Khorramshahr lie in this country on its extreme southwest border. Nakhichevan and Nagorno-Karabakh both border this non-landlocked country. Asiatic cheetahs are found in this country on a plateau bounded by Khorasan and the Elburz and Zagros mountains. This country contains the southern coast of the (*) Caspian Sea as well as the northern coast of a true sea, the Sea of Oman. The Strait of Hormuz, largely controlled by this country, separates that sea from the Persian Gulf, which is named after this country’s historical name. For 10 points, name this Islamic Republic with capital Tehran.

In one poem by this writer, Oswald Wycliffe holds the title Lord Rokeby prisoner. In one of his novels, Julia is involved with Vanbeest Brown, and Ellangowan is inherited by Harry Bertram. In another novel by this author, Desdichado competes in a tournament attended by Athelstane and (*) Locksley. This author’s Guy Mannering, The Bride of Lammermoor, and Rob Roy are included in his Waverley Novels. Another work by this writer features Cedric of Rotherwood, who is the protector of Lady Rowena, a woman who eventually marries the title knight. For 10 points, name this Scottish historical fiction author behind Ivanhoe.

This city was divided into four campans, or zones, each of which was further divided into 20 districts. The Stone of Five Eras was found in the ruins of this city in 1790. This city’s Sacred Precinct was where Pedro de Alvarado killed several thousand people in a pre-emptive attack near the (*) Templo Mayor Complex. The chinampa system of floating gardens was common in this city. La Noche Triste occurred when men under Hernan Cortes tried to leave this city by crossing one of its iconic causeways in 1520. This city rested on islands in Lake Texcoco. For 10 points, name this ancient Aztec capital on which Mexico City was built.
tossups.answer: Tenochtitlan [prompt on Mexico City before mentioned] <LT>

tossups.question: Jason had to control a fire-breathing pair of these animals to earn the Golden Fleece from King Aeetes (“ae-EE-teez”). One of these animals produced food for Ymir (“YI-meer”), and licked blocks of ice in order to sustain itself; it was called Audhumla (“au-DUM-la”) (*). Sekhmet turned into this animal after she consumed a large amount of beer, thinking it to be blood. Hera demanded that Zeus gift Io to her after he turned Io into this animal. One of Hercules’ twelve labors was to capture the Cretan variety of these, and another was to acquire a herd of these animals that belonged to Geryon. For 10 points, name this animal that the Minotaur’s head resembled.
tossups.answer: cow [accept bull, ox, cattle, and other obvious equivalents] <RY>
tossups.answer_formatted: cow [accept bull, ox, cattle, and other obvious equivalents]
acceptable: bull, ox, cattle, and other obvious equivalents

tossups.question: In the first of these works, a crack reveals the eye of one character who has been covered in gold. A man in one of these works runs into a forest after splitting an anvil with a sword. In the last of these works, one character rides a horse into a funeral pyre while (*) wearing a coveted object. The recurring “Death-Curse” of the dwarf Alberich is a leitmotif from these works, which include Götterdämmerung. A low E-flat begins the 136-bar opening to the first of these works. For 10 points, name this group of four operas by Richard Wagner which include Die Walküre and Siegfried.
tossups.answer: Ring Cycle operas [accept clear equivalents; accept The Ring of the Nibelung operas; accept Der Ring des Nibelungen operas; prompt on Richard Wagner operas until “rides a horse” is read; do not accept or prompt on individual works] <GA>
tossups.answer_formatted: Ring Cycle operas [accept clear equivalents; accept The Ring of the Nibelung operas; accept Der Ring des Nibelungen operas; prompt on Richard Wagner operas until “rides a horse” is read; do not accept or prompt on "individual works"]
acceptable: The Ring of the Nibelung operas
promptable: Richard Wagner operas until “rides a horse” is read

tossups.question: This leader’s representatives signed the Treaty of Jassy with the Ottoman Empire, which formally recognized Russian control of the Crimea. Diderot (“DI-duh-row”) notably criticized a law code put forth during this leader’s attempts at Enlightened Despotism. That law code was the (*) Nakaz. Earlier in this monarch’s reign, General Peter Panin helped to suppress the Cossack Pugachev’s rebellion. Lovers of this ruler include the namesake of a famous diamond, Grigory Orlov, and a man who built fake villages for one of her inspection tours, Grigory Potemkin. For 10 points, name this longest serving female ruler of Russia.
tossups.answer: Catherine the Great [accept Catherine II; accept Sophie Friederike Auguste von Anhalt-Zerbst-Dornburg] <LT>
tossups.answer_formatted: Catherine the Great [accept Catherine II; accept Sophie Friederike Auguste von Anhalt-Zerbst-Dornburg]

tossups.question: In the movie EuroTrip, a character played by this actor sings the song “Scotty Doesn’t Know.” This actor has received Emmy nominations for co-producing the series Project Greenlight, and has earned Oscar nominations for producing Manchester by the Sea and playing Francois Pienaar in Invictus. This man is often kicked off of (*) Jimmy Kimmel Live!, usually due to lack of time, but later retaliated with a takeover of the show. This Bostonian actor won an Oscar at only 27 years old, for co-writing the screenplay to the film Good Will Hunting with his longtime friend, Ben Affleck. For 10 points, name this actor most famous for playing Jason Bourne.

This scientist’s findings were used by Archibald Garrod to study alkaptonuria. The author of Intracellular Pangenesis, Carl Correns, worked with theories by this scientist, as did Hugo de Vries. R. A. Fisher used Pearson’s chi-squared test to accuse this scientist of (*) falsifying data because the ratios in his experiments were “too perfect.” This founder of the Austrian Meteorological Society described his research on Pisum sativum in one paper, “Experiments on Plant Hybridization,” which introduced the laws of segregation and independent assortment. For 10 points, identify this scientist and friar who studied genetics using pea plants.
tossups.answer: Gregor Johann Mendel [accept Rehor Jan Mendel] <CL>

tossups.question: One writer in this movement wrote Guilty of Everything and is named Herbert Huncke. Another writer in this movement wrote a book narrated by drug addict William Lee, Naked Lunch. In addition to William S. Burroughs, this movement included the founder of bookstore (*) City Lights. Works in this movement include one addressed to the writer’s mother, Naomi. That author of “Kaddish” was a member of this movement and also wrote a poem with repeats, “I’m with you in Rockland,” and opens, “I saw the best minds of my generation destroyed by madness.” For 10 points, identify this American literary movement featuring works like Allen Ginsberg’s “Howl.”
tossups.answer: The Beat Generation [accept Beat poetry; accept the Beatniks; accept most things that mention Beat] <CL>
tossups.answer_formatted: The Beat Generation [accept Beat poetry; accept the Beatniks; accept most things that mention Beat]

tossups.question: This element’s fusion is the first step in the alpha process, and runaway fusion of this element and oxygen causes Type Ia (“one a”) supernovae when the mass exceeds the Chandrasekhar limit. Black dwarfs are made primarily of this element in a (*) crystallized form. This element, along with oxygen and nitrogen, acts as a catalyst for one type of hydrogen fusion in stars. In stars, this element is first created in the triple-alpha cycle, in which three helium-4 nuclei combine to form the nucleus of this element. White dwarfs are primarily made of, for 10 points, what element that usually has atomic mass of 12 and forms allotropes of graphite and diamonds?

One artist updated his work depicting this person by writing Latin words at its base commending those who “fight bravely for the fatherland.” A work by Rembrandt shows this figure playing a harp for a man in a brightly-colored turban and in another work a helmet’s left wing creeps up this figure’s thigh. This figure wears a large garlanded (*) hat and slides a foot through the locks of an enemy in one Renaissance artwork. In another sculpture, this figure’s arm finishes a downward motion after having thrown a stone at a Philistine. For 10 points, name this biblical man who killed Goliath, the subject of a marble sculpture by Michelangelo.
tossups.answer: King David [accept David slaying Goliath or knowledge equivalents before “this figure” is read] <GA>
tossups.answer_formatted: King David [accept David slaying Goliathaccept knowledge equivalents before “this figure” is read]

tossups.question: The name of this religion first appeared in the 1658 Doctrina Christiana, in which it was described to the King of Spain. This religion describes two aspects of a soul, the big good angel and the little good angel, or the (*) gros bon ange and the ti bon ange. It's not deism, but practitioners of this religion believe that the supreme creator does not intervene in human affairs. As a result, worship is directed to spirits subservient to him. Those spirits are called Ioa. Priests in this religion are called houngans or mambos, and are believed to be chosen by dead ancestors. Versions of this religion developed in Cuba, the Dominican Republic, and New Orleans. For 10 points, name this syncretic religion from Haiti that combined Yoruban traditions with Christianity.
tossups.answer: Voodoo [accept Voudon; accept Vaudoux; accept Hoodoo; prompt on descriptive answers or animism] <AG>
tossups.answer_formatted: Voodoo [accept Voudon; accept Vaudoux; accept Hoodoo; prompt on descriptive answers or animism]

tossups.question: This metal is found in a mineral containing three atoms of sodium and six atoms of fluorine per formula unit. A chloride of this element is used as a catalyst in the Friedel-Crafts reaction. An oxide of this metal, (*) corundum, is used as an abrasive due to its hardness of 9.0 on the Mohs scale. The main source of this metal is bauxite, which is refined in the Bayer process to produce a pure oxide of this metal. This metal is then smelt through the Hall-Héroult process, which industrially uses electrolysis in a molten salt bath. For 10 points, name this silvery white metal with atomic number 13 and symbol Al.

This war featured both the last major naval battle involving sailing ships at Sinop and the first major battle involving ironclads at Kinburn. Lord Raglan was a commander during this war. During this war, Colin Campbell’s stopped a ferocious cavalry charge with his (*) “Thin Red Line.” The 1856 Treaty of Paris ended this conflict, which included the Siege of Sevastopol. Florence Nightingale rose to prominence in this war for her efforts relating to field hospitals. For 10 points, name this conflict from 1853 to 1856, which takes its name from a peninsula on the Black Sea, that pitted the Russian Empire against the Ottomans and their British and French allies.

Binet (“BEEN-ay”) advises one character in this work to take up carpentry, and Homais’ (“oh-MAY’S”) career takes off at the end of this book. Earlier in this book, a letter complete with fake tear stains arrives in a basket of apricots. Although one man in this novel initially moves to Tostes with Heloise Dubuc, he and the protagonist spend much of the text living in (*) Yonville. That protagonist pretends to attend weekly piano lessons in order to carry out an affair with Léon after losing Rodolphe’s affections, despite her marriage to the doctor Charles, and at the end of this novel, she kills herself using arsenic. For 10 points, name this novel about Emma, the most famous work of Gustave Flaubert.

In one orchestral work by this composer, a slow crescendo of a B-minor theme builds from low-pitched instruments to a prestissimo finale. This composer included “Sarabande” and “Rigaudon” movements in a work commemorating the 200th anniversary of a noted playwright, his (*) Holberg Suite. Anton Seidl helped orchestrate a set of 66 works by this composer that include “Wedding Day at Troldhaugen” and “March of the Trolls.” This composer of Lyric Pieces also wrote “Morning Mood” to begin the fourth act of a play. For 10 points, name this composer who wrote “In the Hall of the Mountain King” as part of his incidental music to Ibsen’s Peer Gynt.

The value of this for particles equals the quantity the Lorentz factor minus one, times mass times the speed of light. In the absence of outside forces, the value of this for superfluids remains constant. The value of this for a photon is given by multiplying (*) Planck’s constant by frequency. The rotational form of this quantity is given by one half the moment of inertia times the angular velocity squared while for non-relativistic velocities, the translational form is equal to one half of the mass times velocity squared. For 10 points, name this type of energy that is caused by the motion of an object, in contrast with potential energy.

A Confederate attempt to seize control of this modern-day state led by General Henry Hopkins Sibley was thwarted at the Battle of Glorieta Pass. This state’s city of Columbus was the target of a 1916 raid that led to a retaliatory expedition led by John Pershing. It is believed that members of the (*) Narvaez expedition were the first Europeans to visit this modern-day state. This modern-day state was the site of the 1680 Pueblo Revolt against Spanish rule. The Los Alamos research center is located in this state, which served as the location of the nuclear Trinity Test. For 10 points, name this US state with a capital at Santa Fe.

Robert Jarvik’s wife, Marilyn vos Savant, has the highest recorded value for this specific metric according to the Guinness Book of World Records. Mensa is a group that was founded to cater to individuals with very high recorded values for this metric. The Wechsler test returns this type of numerical value, as does the (*) Stanford-Binet test. The median value for this quantity in the United States is one hundred, and it is normally distributed. This metric is often colloquially contrasted with the controversial EQ value. For 10 points, name this value that is thought by some to be a measure of general intelligence.
tossups.answer: Intelligence Quotient [accept IQ; prompt on descriptive or partial answers such as intelligence] <LT>
tossups.answer_formatted: Intelligence Quotient [accept IQ; prompt on descriptive or partial answers such as intelligence]

tossups.question: One line in this work compares wives and children to clothing and brothers to limbs. In this work, one group lets its opponent fire arrows at empty boats in order to collect them. One character in this work murders his foster father and rides the horse Red Hare. Young Phoenix works for one man in this work, and that man and two others take an (*) oath of fraternity in a peach garden. In this work, the Battle of Red Cliffs is lost by Cao Cao, and this work begins during the Yellow Turban Rebellion near the end of the Han dynasty. For 10 points, name this classical Chinese novel by Luo Guanzhong about the conflict between Wei, Shu, and Wu.
tossups.answer: Romance of the Three Kingdoms [accept Sānguó yǎnyì; prompt on The Three Kingdoms] <CL>
tossups.answer_formatted: Romance of the Three Kingdoms [accept Sānguó yǎnyì; prompt on The Three Kingdoms]

tossups.question: . A line from one of this author’s short stories refers to a man who was “born under far bluer skies”. That story, which is set on a passenger liner, is Mr. Know-All. In one novel by this man, the coal baron Lord George runs off to America with Mrs. Driffield. That fact is discovered while this author’s character William Ashenden seeks to write a biography of an author many believe to be modeled on (*) Thomas Hardy. Ashenden is the protagonist of Cakes and Ale. This writer’s most famous work tells the tale of the club-footed Philip Carey’s upbringing. For 10 points, name this English author of the short story Rain and the novel Of Human Bondage.

bonuses.leadin: Only one SI base unit has an SI prefix. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify that unit, the only SI unit which is still defined by an artifact rather than a replicable physical property. In 1795, one thousandth of this unit was defined as the mass of one cubic centimeter of water at 0° Centigrade.
This instrument may one day be able to define the kilogram based on electronic units. It was an improvement from the Ampere balance, and it is based upon a proposal by B. P. Kibble.

In addition to current, watt balances use this property to measure mass. The name “watt balance” comes from the fact that the measured mass is proportional to the product of current and this quantity.

bonuses.leadin: The first recorded king of this nation was Gorm the Old, and its flag is said to have fallen from the heavens at a 1219 battle, making it the oldest continually used national standard. For 10 points each:
answers: Queen Margaret I [accept Margrethe I; prompt on Margaret] <LT>
parts: Name this Scandinavian nation located primarily on the Jutland peninsula. Its capital is Copenhagen.
This union of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden lasted from 1397 to 1523, and notably vied with the Hanseatic League for regional supremacy.

This Danish queen founded the Kalmar Union by acquiring control of Norway and Sweden. Albert of Mecklenburg was a notable rival of hers, and the current queen of Denmark has stated that her decision to be known as “the second” is meant to recognize this ruler.

bonuses.leadin: In this play, it is revealed that a baby was adopted by Polybus from a shepherd on Mount Cithaeron. For 10 points each:
answers: Oedipus Rex [accept Oedipus Tyrannus; accept Oedipus the King; prompt on Oedipus; do not accept or prompt on “Oedipus at Colonus”]
parts: Identify this tragedy in which the title character blinds himself after learning he fulfilled a prophecy by sleeping with his mother and killing his father. At the end of this play, the chorus says to “Look upon that last day always.”
Oedipus Rex and the two plays which follow it among the Theban plays, Oedipus at Colonus and Antigone, are works by this Greek tragedian. There are a total of seven extant tragedies by this writer.

Sophocles also wrote this play about Odysseus’ attempts to win the services of an archer with an injured foot, which is set in Lemnos. It ends with a deus ex machina, as Heracles appears and promises to cure the title character.
answers_formatted: Oedipus Rex [accept Oedipus Tyrannus; accept Oedipus the King; prompt on Oedipus; do not accept or prompt on "“Oedipus at Colonus”"]

bonuses.leadin: This war was sparked by the death of the last Hapsburg in the country in question. For 10 points each:
answers: Treaty of Utrecht or Treaty of Rastatt [accept either underlined portion] <LT>
parts: Name this 1702 to 1715 conflict over who would rule an Iberian nation. It included battles like Blenheim in Europe and extensive military actions in the belligerent nations’ colonial possessions.

This British queen for much of the war is the namesake of both the North American portion of the war and a style of furniture. This female monarch oversaw the 1707 Act of Union and was the last Stuart ruler of the British isles.

Name either of the two treaties that ended the War of the Spanish Succession. In these treaties, Great Britain received Minorca but the Asiento monopoly, while the Austrians received many of Spain’s continental possessions outside of Iberia.
answers_formatted: Treaty of Utrecht or Treaty of Rastatt [accept either underlined portion]
acceptable: Treaty of Utrecht or Treaty of Rastatt

bonuses.leadin: This structure is extremely susceptible to cancer that can be spread through HPV infections. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this lower part of the uterus that functions as a connection between the main part of the uterus and the vagina. Its namesake canal is the primary conduit for sperm.
This substance is used to approximate whether or not a woman is ovulating in the Billings Method. During pregnancy, a plug composed of this substance forms.
A pregnancy is terminated and a fetus’ life ends in this type of medical procedure. Some late-term varieties of this procedure involve cervical dilation.

bonuses.leadin: She named some of the figures she studied David Greybeard, Goliath, and Mike. For 10 points each:
answers: chimpanzees [prompt on apes; do not accept “monkeys”]
parts: Name this British researcher whose work challenged the long-standing notion that only humans made and used tools.
The subjects of Goodall’s research were these primates. She observed that they would often hunt and eat smaller colobus monkeys.
Goodall performed her research primarily at Gombe Stream National Park in this Eastern African nation, which contains the city of Dar es Salaam.

bonuses.leadin: This philosopher is widely misunderstood and often associated with Nazism, despite not actually being an anti-Semite. For 10 points each:
answers: Thus Spoke Zarathustra [or Thus Spake Zarathustra; accept Also Sprach Zarathustra]
parts: Name this mustachioed German philosopher who famously proclaimed “God is Dead.”
This book contains the famous quote “God is Dead” and details the travelings of a title character who shares a name with a crucial figure of Zoroastrianism. It is subtitled “A Book for All and None.”

[10] In Thus Spoke Zarathustra, this crucial German concept details the idea of a superior man who is seen as the goal for humanity. This specific German word is often translated as “superman”, and it became an important concept in anarchist and fascist thought.
answers_formatted: Thus Spoke Zarathustra [or Thus Spake Zarathustra; accept Also Sprach Zarathustra]

bonuses.leadin: Name some stuff about South American grasslands, for 10 points each:
parts: The Pampas, known for their cowboys called gauchos, are in Uruguay, Brazil, and this country. This country’s capital of Buenos Aires lies in the Pampas on the Rio de la Plata, across from Montevideo.

This diverse geographic region, consisting of grasslands, mountains, and deserts, also lies in Argentina and was mistakenly thought to have giants by early explorers. Shared with Chile, it takes up the southernmost triangle of South America.
This other grassland region surrounds the Orinoco River in Venezuela and Colombia. The cowboys of this region formed much of Simon Bolivar’s army in the Venezuelan War of Independence.

bonuses.leadin: MODERATOR NOTE: In the first bonus part, put emphasis on the word “composer.” This composer reputedly wrote his “Chelsea Bridge” after seeing a Battersea Bridge painting while visiting Europe. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this American composer of a jazz song about a subway line in Harlem, titled “Take the A Train.”

This NYC-based jazz musician and his band popularized “Take the A Train” in the 1940s, in addition to several other collaborations with Billy Strayhorn. This pianist also composed “It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing).”

In the opening song of this musical, the protagonist Usnavi modifies the original jazz lyrics by singing “you must take the A train / Even farther than Harlem to northern Manhattan.” It’s not Hamilton, but this musical was written by Hunter alum Lin-Manuel Miranda, and it is set in the title Dominican-American NYC neighborhood.

bonuses.leadin: One character in this novel hires the private investigator Chilon Chilonides. For 10 points each:
answers: Quo Vadis: A Narrative of the Time of Nero [accept Quo vadis. Powieść z czasów Nerona; grudgingly accept Where Are You Going? or Whither Goest Thou?; prompt on subtitle]
Republic of Poland [accept Congress Poland; prompt on Union of Soviet Socialist Republics or Soviet Union]
Elie Wiesel [accept Eliezer Wiesel; accept Elyezer Vizel] <CL/LT>
parts: Identify this pro-Christian novel in which Marcus Vinicius falls in love with Calina, who is usually known as Ligia. Early in this novel, Acte promises to protect Ligia from the emperor’s lust.
Quo Vadis was written by Henryk Sienkiewicz (“shi-EN-kee-wreets”), an author from this nation. Alan Furst described this country in the novel The Spies of Warsaw.
This Jewish author’s most famous work is partly set in Poland. That work is Night, and this author also wrote The Trial of God.
answers_formatted: Quo Vadis: A Narrative of the Time of Nero [accept Quo vadis. Powieść z czasów Nerona; grudgingly accept Where Are You Going? or Whither Goest Thou?; prompt on subtitle]
Republic of Poland [accept Congress Poland; prompt on Union of Soviet Socialist Republics or Soviet Union]
acceptable: Quo Vadis: A Narrative of the Time of Nero
Quo vadis. Powieść z czasów Nerona

bonuses.leadin: Alviss the dwarf was very abused during his lifetime. Answer some questions about him for 10 points each:
parts: Alviss was killed by this Norse god. He once lost a wrestling match to a personification of Old Age, and he will kill his archenemy, the World Serpent, at Ragnarok before walking nine paces and dying.

Thor was unhappy about his daughter Thrud being promised to Alviss, so he asked Alviss questions to test his wisdom until the sun came up, which did this to the dwarf. The gaze of Medusa also performed this action.
Being a dwarf, Alviss’ homeworld would have been this dark world in Norse mythology.

bonuses.leadin: In this novel, William, the heir to Kellynch, first notices the protagonist on a trip through Lyme Regis. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this novel which ends when Anne Elliot and Commander Frederick Wentworth finally renew their engagement and are wed. That engagement was originally broken due to the efforts of Sir Walter and Lady Russell.
This other novel by the author of Persuasion features the Dashwood sisters, Elinor and Marianne, who eventually marry Edward Ferrars and Colonel Brandon, respectively.
Persuasion and Sense and Sensibility are both works by this British author of Mansfield Park, Northanger Abbey, and Pride and Prejudice.

bonuses.leadin: This country was once home to the Wafd Party. For 10 points each:
answers: United Arab Republic [accept United Arab Commonwealth] <LT>
parts: Name this North African nation that was the site of the Urabi Revolt. It is home to many pyramids.
This man led Egypt from 1956 until his 1970 death. He is famous for leading Egypt during the Six Day War and for nationalizing the Suez Canal.
One of Nasser’s pet schemes was this short-lived political union between Egypt and Syria. It ended when a 1961 military coup overthrew this government in Syria and restored the Syrian Republic.

bonuses.leadin: This country has recently faced an economic crisis as a result of a significant reduction in coal exports to China. For 10 points each:
answers: North Korea [accept Democratic People’s Republic of Korea; prompt on Korea]
missile test [accept nuclear test or ballistic missile test or any kind of descriptive answer]
parts: Name this East Asian Communist state with a capital at Pyongyang. It is currently led by Kim Jong Un.

The United Nations Security Council has condemned these specific actions undertaken by North Korea under Kim Jong Un. Most recently, North Korea claimed that one of these actions was in response to a yearly joint military exercise called “Foal Eagle.”
Missile tests are not the only thing that North Korea does that enrages the free world. This American college student has been imprisoned for over a year in North Korea for stealing a sign.
answers_formatted: North Korea [accept Democratic People’s Republic of Korea; prompt on Korea]
missile test [accept nuclear test or ballistic missile test or any kind of descriptive answer]

bonuses.leadin: Members of this group published an almanac that included analysis of works by composers Scriabin, Berg, and Webern. For 10 points each:
answers: The Blue Rider [or Der Blaue Reiter]
Degenerate Art Exhibition [accept Die Ausstellung Entartete Kunst] <GA>
parts: Name this early 20th century movement pioneered by a group of Russian and German visual artists who aimed to express spiritual truths in their artwork. Important members included August Macke and Franz Marc.
This artist of a painting with the same name later became a leader of The Blue Rider alongside Franz Marc. This Russian artist also created several “improvisations” and “compositions.”

Several of Kandinsky’s artworks were included in a Nazi Germany art exhibition with this title, which derided works opposed to the Nazi ideal. This exhibition also included works by Ukrainian Jewish artist Marc Chagall.

bonuses.leadin: According to Joseph Asagai, one member of this family “mutilates” herself by straightening her hair. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this family which includes Lena, Beneatha, Walter, Ruth, and Travis, all of whom live in a small South Side apartment in Chicago before moving to an all-white neighborhood.
The Youngers must decide what to do with a ten thousand dollar life insurance check in this play. In this play, Willy and Bobo steal the money Walter plans to invest in a liquor store.
A Raisin in the Sun is a work by this American playwright behind The Drinking Gourd and The Sign in Sidney Brustein’s Window.

bonuses.leadin: Two of these numbers are 6 and 28. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these natural numbers that are neither abundant nor deficient.
This man found a formula generating all even perfect numbers using Mersenne primes. He is more famous for writing Elements, a text on geometry.
All known perfect numbers are also these numbers, which form the third diagonal in Pascal’s triangle. The square root of the sum of the first n cubic numbers is the nth one of these numbers.

bonuses.leadin: August Ludwig added a “Philosopher’s Scherzo” and “March of Destiny” to the end of this work. For 10 points each:
answers: The “Unfinished” Symphony [or Unvollendete; accept Franz Schubert’s Symphony No. 8 in B minor; prompt on Schubert’s 8th; prompt on Symphony No. 8; prompt on clear knowledge equivalents]
parts: Name this orchestral work whose original composer died before completing its third movement.
The Unfinished Symphony was written by this composer of Winterreise. He also wrote the lied (“LEED”) Gretchen at the Spinning Wheel as well as the Trout Quintet.
Schubert also composed eight of these solo piano pieces one year prior to his death. Chopin composed a “Fantaisie” one of these in 1834.
answers_formatted: The “Unfinished” Symphony [or Unvollendete; accept Franz Schubert’s Symphony No. 8 in B minor; prompt on Schubert’s 8th; prompt on Symphony No. 8; prompt on clear knowledge equivalents]
acceptable: Franz Schubert’s Symphony No. 8 in B minor

bonuses.leadin: Some presidencies have more scandals than others. For 10 points each:
answers: William Jefferson “Bill” Clinton [accept William Jefferson Blythe III]
parts: Name this scandal-ridden US President who was in office from 1993-2001. Formerly, he had served as the Governor of Arkansas, and his wife, Hillary, lost the 2016 US Presidential Election.

Bill Clinton lied about having sexual relations with this White House intern under oath, leading Congress to impeach Clinton. A blue dress belong to this woman was a notable piece of evidence during Clinton’s trial in the Senate.

This other Clinton-related scandal involved a failed land development deal in Arkansas in the 1970s and 1980s. Bill Clinton pardoned one of the primary actors in this scandal, Susan McDougal, right before he left office.

bonuses.leadin: A small village on an island in Sweden has four elements named after it. For 10 points each:
answers: ytterbium, yttrium, terbium, erbium [accept any underlined portion]
gadolinite [do not accept or prompt on “gadolinium”]
parts: Name any one of those four elements.
Name this mineral, the source of several rare earth elements, including ytterbium, yttrium, terbium, and erbium. It was named for a Finnish mineralogist.
This group of the periodic table, also called the rare earths, contains ytterbium, terbium, and erbium. This group is very similar to the actinides, which are one period below it.

bonuses.leadin: . The person who performs this action in one painting forms the apex of a triangle alongside a ship’s sails. For 10 points each:
answers: waving a handkerchief [accept variants, such as waving a cloth; accept just waving; prompt on signaling or other non-specific actions]

The Charging Chasseur [accept An Officer of the Imperial Horse Guards Charging; accept Officer of the Chasseurs Commanding a Charge; accept Officier de chasseurs à cheval de la garde impériale chargeant] <GA>
parts: Name this action which is performed by an African member of the crew of the namesake ship in The Raft of the Medusa. This action is performed due to the sighting of the Argus, which did not ultimately rescue the sinking ship.
Raft of the Medusa was the masterpiece of this French artist, who frequently used corpses as models.
In this other painting by Géricault, a horse rears amongst a scene of carnage during a battle. The horse’s rider is a cavalry officer whose hat is several times the size of his head.
answers_formatted: waving a handkerchief [accept variants, such as waving a cloth; accept just waving; prompt on signaling or other non-specific actions]

The Charging Chasseur [accept An Officer of the Imperial Horse Guards Charging; accept Officer of the Chasseurs Commanding a Charge; accept Officier de chasseurs à cheval de la garde impériale chargeant]
acceptable: variants, such as waving a cloth
